LGTM

Alternatively, [ConcurrentLinkedHashMap](https://github.com/ben-manes/concurrentlinkedhashmap) is a concurrent, LRU cache that supports weighted entries. That might be a good stop-gap to offer much of the Caffeine-based extension's [performance](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Benchmarks), except for the improved eviction policy. The cache was fairly successful, e.g. adopted by Cassandra and ported into Guava (though at a large perf loss). It is also Java 6 compatible.
Have you tried using `""` for missing?

@drcrallen not in the context of an actual extractionFn; is there a test that verifies that works as expected? If so then that's a good workaround.

Although even then, allowing `null` to mean "drop out of the lookup" seems like a nicer experience for users when the input json file may not be totally immaculate.
So is the expected behavior of `null` to be "not included in lookup" or to be "map to missing"?
I'd expect a null value or an empty string to both behave the same as if the row weren't there at all, and all three of those situations should be returned as `null` by the extractionFns.
üëç
@guobingkun and @himanshug what is the status about this PR ? we might need something like this soon ?
Ping ?
@ben-manes Thanks for the suggestion. Is it easy to implement the eviction policy in ConcurrentLinkedHashMap?

CLHM is an LRU policy on top of ConcurrentHashMap. Its intentionally bare bones because it took me a long time to stumble on the right design ideas. The challenge with LRU is that every read is a write to global, shared state. The solution is to use a database style commit log to record and replay events. We then tried to retrofit the ideas onto Guava and I rewrote it in [Caffeine](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine).

So if you're asking if its easy to use here for an LRU cache, then [yes](https://github.com/ben-manes/concurrentlinkedhashmap/wiki/ExampleUsage).

``` java
ConcurrentMap<K, V> cache = new ConcurrentLinkedHashMap.Builder<K, V>()
    .maximumWeightedCapacity(1000)
    .weigher(...)
    .build();
```

If you're asking if its easy to implement the ideas from scratch, then its moderate. But doing it with all the features and tuning in Caffeine was [hard](http://highscalability.com/blog/2016/1/25/design-of-a-modern-cache.html). However that also replaced LRU with a modern policy, which is one of the reasons why Druid [0.9.2](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3503) adopted it as an extension. Maybe when Druid is JDK8-based they'll make it the default.
Sorry wrong PR destination, it needs internal testing first.
üëç

IMHO we shouldn't try to reinvent the wheel here. The local cache in druid has tons of problems that make it unsuitable once you get to any appreciable scale, which is why I took @ben-manes 's advice and checked out Caffeine, which is working great for us.

The simple local cache does, however, provide a great way to spin up a mild druid cluster with minimal overhead.
I'm not saying it _shouldn't_ be fixed, but I think focus should be on getting the default local cache more functional and usable, rather than trying to write the-next-big-cache.

Ok, so this foregoes the LinkedHashMap's remove eldest entry hook in order to ensure the cache size never exceeds the configured value in the put call itself. Or more precisely, it will evict until either there is enough room or the cache is empty.

Thread safety is retained through `io.druid.client.cache.MapCache#clearLock` , but the contract for `LinkedHashMap` already mandates external synchronization. So that's ok.

Looks good from here.

I'm testing this internally right now to make sure the fix works as expected, please hold off on merging for a bit.

@drcrallen this is for Spark compatibility, right? Is it possible to get Spark to do either classpath reordering or classloader isolation to work around this? I ask because in our testing, it _is_ possible to get hadoop to work¬†with the following versions, even when they are built against an older guava (using the properties mentioned in the other-hadoop.md doc file).

If it's possible to make Spark do something similar, I think that'd be good, because then we don't have to worry as much about updating our dependencies.
- emr472
- emr500
- quickstart.cloudera
- sandbox.hortonworks.com
- sequenceiq-230
- sequenceiq-240
- sequenceiq-241
- sequenceiq-250
- sequenceiq-251
- sequenceiq-252
- sequenceiq-260
- sequenceiq-271
@gianm I agree being able to upgrade reasonably would be nice. I'm testing `spark.driver.userClassPathFirst` to see if it works in this case

- being able to set a tier's priority dynamically in the coordinator

Ah, nevermind, that's only the client the broker uses to talk to data nodes. The other client used for other stuff doesn't have its configs documented.
LGTM not sure if we should do the check for empty as null as well.

It looks like this treats `targetPartitionSize` as a total byte size of input files, whereas all the other partition specs treat it as a number of rows in the output segments. The inconsistency there is going to be confusing, maybe there's some better way we can model this. Perhaps abandon calling this config `targetPartitionSize` and instead call it `targetInputBytes`.

With that change I think this is a useful feature for a specific use case.

Docs would be good too please, especially mentioning the case that this would be useful in.

Quick question about the DataSketch histogram implementation contained in this PR - is this feature still on the roadmap? We've been looking into Druid for analytics and have a req to surface medians and histograms, but are seeing degradation in query times using the current approxHistogram aggregator (20-30s for an uncached query). There's still a bit of investigation to be done on our end around tuning the `resolution` but we're interested in this alternate implementation if it's more accurate and in the single second range for larger datasources.

I see an off-heap implementation is remaining, is this a blocker on using the extension? Has anyone tried running this branch in production?
I am ok with this change.
The select query is generally incompatible with sorting. Maybe this could be done as part of a new query.

did a quick scan, overall looks fine to me... can give a more careful look next week.
